newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Americas ministers discuss region-wide trade bloc.
newsitem.headline: Americas ministers discuss region-wide trade bloc.

text.p: Deputy commerce ministers from the Americas gathered in the northeastern Brazilian resort of Recife on Tuesday for a three-day meeting on establishing a regional free trade zone, officials said.

Brazilian newspapers reported that the summit, which will debate the Free Trade Area of the Americas (FTAA), would be a stage for a scuffle between Brazil, its Mercosur trade bloc partners and the United States and Canada.
"What's at stake here is who is going to have influence over the continent in the next century," a Brazilian Foreign Ministry official told the financial daily Gazeta Mercantil.

Newspapers said Canada and the United States were pushing for talks on reducing tariffs in the FTAA to start by March next year. The region-wide free trade zone is meant to come into existence by the year 2005.

Brazil believes that the Mercosur trade bloc, which groups Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, must be strengthened first as a counterweight to the bulk of Nafta, grouping the United States, Canada and Mexico.
Brazilian officials also say that talks on business facilitation -- basically levelling the playing field between FTAA countries -- must precede tariff negotiations.
In an opening speech, Brazilian Foreign Minister Luiz Felipe Lampreia made his country's standpoint clear.

Noting Mercosur's free trade deals with Chile and Bolivia and another under negotiation with the Andean Pact countries, Lampreia said the FTAA must be based on the "building blocks" already established in the region.

"Mercosur is a success story that is here to stay, one that strengthens the international identity of its members and gives critical mass to the FTAA," he said, according to a copy of the speech prepared for delivery.
The Recife meeting is aimed at preparing for a full ministerial meeting of the 34 FTAA signatory countries due to take place in the Brazilian city of Belo Horizonte on May 13-16 this year.
Another final preparatory meeting was scheduled for April in Rio de Janeiro, Brazilian officials said.
